snippet.textDisplay:
The piece by Blur Studios is actually a AMD's marketing spot. I know blur and while they were good at making game cinematics, Terminator is their first major foray in hollywood vfx industry where they are far from a top studio. ILM, Pixar, Weta, Luma Pictures ..... are all Intel/Nvidia based to this and will remain so.
Also, while they did use a couple of Threadripper based workstations the bulk of the work was still handled by HP's xeon based workstations.
snippet.textOriginal:
The piece by Blur Studios is actually a AMD's marketing spot. I know blur and while they were good at making game cinematics, Terminator is their first major foray in hollywood vfx industry where they are far from a top studio. ILM, Pixar, Weta, Luma Pictures ..... are all Intel/Nvidia based to this and will remain so.
Also, while they did use a couple of Threadripper based workstations the bulk of the work was still handled by HP's xeon based workstations.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi. ACTUAL audio engineer here.

There is nothing about the Mac Pro that would benefit our work loads whatsoever that isn't already present in other hardware already, and with that disgusting price tag, building is just a no brainer. Those comments are all from Logic Pro fanboys, and the eletism amongst apple users in the audio community is deeply rooted. There has been this spoof going around for a couple decades now where some people think Macs are for audio workloads, and studio work (for some reason) can't even be done on a PC.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hi. ACTUAL audio engineer here. 

There is nothing about the Mac Pro that would benefit our work loads whatsoever that isn't already present in other hardware already, and with that disgusting price tag, building is just a no brainer. Those comments are all from Logic Pro fanboys, and the eletism amongst apple users in the audio community is deeply rooted. There has been this spoof going around for a couple decades now where some people think Macs are for audio workloads, and studio work (for some reason) can't even be done on a PC.

snippet.textDisplay: Apple most likely designed this thing 2 years ago and just stood on it to wait for a good time to launch. snippet.textDisplay: I cannot believe you didn't mention Thunderbolt. It's not a gaming machine. Until today, in fact, no AMD computer had Thunderbolt. It's not all about speed. It's also just not how the world works; Apple has a relationship with Intel, for better or worse and these contracts likely last years. I have to say it's plain silly to say that AMD is taking seconds to do tasks that used to take minutes, but Intel can't match that performance, when there's only double digit percentage point differences here, not 60x! Let's not overstate this. No, I am no fan of Intel.
snippet.textOriginal: I cannot believe you didn't mention Thunderbolt. It's not a gaming machine. Until today, in fact, no AMD computer had Thunderbolt. It's not all about speed. It's also just not how the world works; Apple has a relationship with Intel, for better or worse and these contracts likely last years. I have to say it's plain silly to say that AMD is taking seconds to do tasks that used to take minutes, but Intel can't match that performance, when there's only double digit percentage point differences here, not 60x! Let's not overstate this. No, I am no fan of Intel.

snippet.textDisplay:
Linus don't seem to understand ....

Do creative professionals really NEED 3990X right now?

Most, if not all creative professionals don't even need 28cores, let alone 64cores. What apps, actually utilitizes 64cores?

Their main concern is expandability (PCI lanes, TB3 slots, almost zero accessories take adv of PCI4.0), memory (>512GB), noise (silent), and compatibility (OSX)

Yes, Threadripper is faster and cheaper, but they don't need that power right now, and it's memory capped.

So at the end, although threadripper may be a great use cases for scientific applications where it's not memory intensive, Intel still has it's use case.
snippet.textOriginal:
Linus don't seem to understand ....

Do creative professionals really NEED 3990X right now?

Most, if not all creative professionals don't even need 28cores, let alone 64cores. What apps, actually utilitizes 64cores?

Their main concern is expandability (PCI lanes, TB3 slots, almost zero accessories take adv of PCI4.0), memory (>512GB), noise (silent), and compatibility (OSX)

Yes, Threadripper is faster and cheaper, but they don't need that power right now, and it's memory capped.

So at the end, although threadripper may be a great use cases for scientific applications where it's not memory intensive, Intel still has it's use case.

snippet.textDisplay: In the professional audio world, Thunderbolt 3 reigns supreme for external connectivity and this probably explains why Apple was forced to stick with Intel this time around. Once USB 4 starts arriving, considering that Thunderbolt 3 is encapsulated within USB 4, I’d be surprised if Apple didn’t start moving towards high end AMD CPUs pretty quickly. They obviously have a good relationship with AMD and such a move on the CPU front seems like a win/win.
snippet.textOriginal: In the professional audio world, Thunderbolt 3 reigns supreme for external connectivity and this probably explains why Apple was forced to stick with Intel this time around. Once USB 4 starts arriving, considering that Thunderbolt 3 is encapsulated within USB 4, I’d be surprised if Apple didn’t start moving towards high end AMD CPUs pretty quickly. They obviously have a good relationship with AMD and such a move on the CPU front seems like a win/win.

snippet.textDisplay: One thing I tried to do was trying to build a machine that would be better than the 6000$ Mac Pro, but the max I could go was 5000$, and here is the machine I build (https://pcpartpicker.com/list/tRT2b8), I know there are thing that could be better, basically everything from the monitor to bellow, the OS would be both Windows 10 and Linux Ubuntu 18.04LTS, Linux isn't there because is a free OS, and if you have a problem with non RGB keyboard, I don't like having my pc looking like a disco party, been this is me and I am ok with someone wanting a pc that looks like a disco party, next why 2 GPU's? 1st 2 way crossfire and to work as a backup GPU in case the main one breaks, and last, why 6 storage device? to do RAID 10 and yes the motherboard supports RAID 10, if you think there is something better for one of the components that I choose, comment here and with a reason.
snippet.textOriginal: One thing I tried to do was trying to build a machine that would be better than the 6000$ Mac Pro, but the max I could go was 5000$, and here is the machine I build (https://pcpartpicker.com/list/tRT2b8), I know there are thing that could be better, basically everything from the monitor to bellow, the OS would be both Windows 10 and Linux Ubuntu 18.04LTS, Linux isn't there because is a free OS, and if you have a problem with non RGB keyboard, I don't like having my pc looking like a disco party, been this is me and I am ok with someone wanting a pc that looks like a disco party, next why 2 GPU's? 1st 2 way crossfire and to work as a backup GPU in case the main one breaks, and last, why 6 storage device? to do RAID 10 and yes the motherboard supports RAID 10, if you think there is something better for one of the components that I choose, comment here and with a reason.
